default: a {@filter simple weapon|items|source=phb|category=basic|type=simple weapon} and a set of {@item artisan's tools|phb} of your choice
(a) a {@item studded leather armor|phb} or (b) a {@item scale mail|phb}
a {@item light crossbow|phb} and 20 {@item crossbow bolt|phb|bolts}
Two {@item tinker's tools|phb} and a {@item dungeoneer's pack|phb}

fluff.name: The Artificer
entries: A graying gnome hunched over his workbench, carefully adjusting the clockwork mechanism that would power his creation. Before him laid an automaton of intricate iron gears within a suit of plate armor, built to resemble a large gnome. As the tiny inventor affixed his signature mithril mustache to the face plate, a jolt of electric-blue magic flashed from the automaton. With a sharp motion, the Steel Defender sat upright and awaited the first command of its creator.

The goblin delicately made his way down the tunnel that he had booby-trapped with vials of noxious fumes and acids. This was the third time this year his clan had moved burrows to avoid being raided by adventuring parties, and the inventive goblin was determined to protect the newest home burrow. He was confident that this time he would stop the adventurers that always seemed to find their way to his home.

A young human woman, wearing a leather apron over her fine clothes, flexed the steel gauntlet she had just enchanted. As she closed her fist the gauntlet let forth a blinding arc of lavender lightning, destroying the table on the opposite side of the room. As the dust settled, she affixed the gauntlet to her now complete suit of Arcane Armor. When she revealed this, her latest creation, to her father, he would have no choice but to finally show her his approval.

entries.name: Masters of Innovation
entries: Relentless in their pursuit of innovation, artificers are defined by their insatiable curiosity and willingness to push the limits of arcane invention, even at great risk to themselves. For most artificers, they stake their personal value on the fruits of their experimentation, and they see mastering the basics of their chosen craft as the first step toward true greatness.

Deep down, the goal of every artificer is the discovery of a new groundbreaking invention, magical or otherwise. Some artificers are engineers, students of science and warfare, who bring their considerable intellect to bear to construct deadly weapons augmented with magic. Others view themselves as artists, combining the rigid formulas of arcane magic with the artisanal touch of their own specialized tools and spells.

entries.name: Fierce Rivalries
entries: Almost every artificer has a rival, most often another artificer who they seek to outdo at every turn. These intense rivalries are the sole motivation of some artificers, and outdoing their rival is more valuable than any fame or riches they could gain from their discoveries. Many are willing to risk everything they have to achieve a new breakthrough before their rival.

By the same token, artificers with similar philosophies and aims often band together in loose artisan's guilds. They share insights and discoveries, hoping to keep ahead of rival guilds by pooling resources and working as a team. However, even when working together, most artificers are protective of any insights they think could lead to a groundbreaking discovery.

entries.name: Creating Your Artificer
entries: When creating an artificer, think about their background and drive for adventure. Who is their rival and what event started their feud? What is your artificer's relationship with the artisan who taught them the basics of their craft? Are they part of a guild? What role do artificers play in the campaign world? Do artificer guilds exist in all the major cities or are you the first person to pursue the path of arcane invention?

Most importantly, what does your artifice look like? Not all arcane inventors work with gears and grease. Is your artificer the student of a hag who uses weird magick to imbue totems of bone with arcane energy? Or, are you an enchanter who carves elvish runes into elaborate wooden wands and staffs?

entries.name: Quick Build
entries: You can make a Artificer quickly by following these suggestions. First, make Intelligence your highest ability score, followed by Dexterity. Second, choose the {@background guild artisan|phb|artisan} background. Third, choose the {@optfeature enhanced defense|LLAART} and {@optfeature repeating shot|LLAART} infusions.

classFeature.name: Infusions
entries: You have learned to imbue objects with your signature brand of magic in order to produce wondrous items. At 1st level, you learn two {@filter Infusions|optionalfeatures|feature type=LLAART:INF} of your choice from the list at the end of this class. The Infusions Known column of the artificer table shows when you learn more Infusions of your choice.
At the end of a long rest, as long as you have tinker's tools, you can replace one Infusion you know with another Infusion of your choice, so long as you meet all of its prerequisites.

entries.name: Infusing an Object
entries: At the end of a long rest, you can use your tinker's tools to imbue an Infusion you know into a nonmagical object. To do so, you must be able to touch the object with your tools.

If the Infusion requires attunement, you can attune to the object the instant you infuse it, or you can forgo attunement so another creature can attune to it. To attune to the infused item later, you must follow the normal attunement process.

The Infusion remains in an item indefinitely. If you die, the Infusion vanishes after a number of days have passed equal to your Intelligence modifier (minimum of 1 day). Infusions vanish immediately if you give up your knowledge of one to learn another or imbue the Infusion into another object.

You can infuse multiple objects at the end of each long rest, up to one for each Infusion you know. Each Infusion can be in only one object at a time, and no object can bear more than one Infusion. If you transfer an Infusion to a new object, any previous instance of that Infusion immediately ends.

entries.name: Replicate Magic Item
entries: You can also use your Infusions to replicate magic items that you have studied. Over the course of a long rest, you can use tinker's tools to examine a magic item you can touch. At the end of that long rest, you can replace one of your Infusions Known with the knowledge of this magic item. After which, you can infuse an object with the properties of that magic item, following all the rules for your other Infusions.

You can use this feature to replicate any item of Common rarity. As you gain artificer levels you can use this feature to replicate items of increasing rarity: Uncommon at 5th level, Rare at 11th level, and finally Very Rare items at 17th level.

classFeature.name: Specialization
entries: At 1st level, choose a Specialization that best represents the arcane research and inventions of your artificer.
Your Specialization grants features at 1st level, and again when you reach 3rd, 5th, 9th, and 15th level in this class.

classFeature.name: Spellcasting
entries: At 2nd level, you can use your tools and your signature brand of magic to produce strange and wondrous spell effects from objects and tools that you imbue with arcane power.

entries.name: Cantrips
entries: At 2nd level, you learn two cantrips of your choice from the {@filter Artificer spell list|spells|class=Artificer (Alternate) (LLAART)}. You learn an additional Artificer cantrip of your choice at 4th level and another at 10th level.

entries.name: Spell Slots
entries: The Artificer table shows how many spell slots you have to cast your spells of 1st-level and higher. To cast a spell, you must expend a slot equal to the spell's level or higher. You regain all expended spell slots when you finish a long rest.
For example, if you know the 1st-level spell {@spell magic missile} and have a 1st-level and a 2nd-level spell slot available, you can cast {@spell magic missile} using either spell slot.

entries.name: Spells Known of 1st-level and Higher
entries: You know two 1st-level spells of your choice from the {@filter Artificer spell list|spells|class=Artificer (Alternate) (LLAART)}. The Spells Known column of the Artificer Table shows when you learn more Artificer spells of your choice. The Spells Known column of the Artificer table shows when you learn more artificer spells of your choice. Each spell must be of a level for which you have spell slots. For example, when you reach 5th level in this class, you can learn one new artificer spell of either 1st or 2nd-level.
When you gain a level in this class, you can replace one of the artificer spells you know with another artificer spell for which you have spell slots.

entries.name: Spellcasting Ability
entries: Intelligence is the spellcasting ability for your artificer spells, as you use your knowledge of the arcane to cast spells. You use your Intelligence when a spell refers to your spellcasting ability, when you set a saving throw DC for an artificer spell, or when you make a spell attack roll for an artificer spell.

entries.name: Spellcasting Focus
entries: You must use either your tinker's tools, a set of {@item artisan's tools|phb} with which you are proficient, or an item bearing one of your Infusions as the spellcasting focus for your artificer spells.

While you have access to your tinker's tools, you know both the {@spell mending} cantrip and {@spell identify}, but they don't count against your number of Spells Known. You can use your tinker's tools to cast identify by spending a spell slot, or as a ritual spell.

classFeature.name: Specialization Spells
entries: Each Specialization has a list of Specialization Spells that you learn at the artificer levels noted in its description. These Specialization Spells count as artificer spells for you, but they don't count against your total number of Spells Known.

classFeature.name: Specialization Feature
entries: At 3rd level, you gain a feature granted by your Specialization.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 4th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Specialization Feature
entries: At 5th level, you gain a feature granted by your Specialization.

classFeature.name: Adjustable Infusions
entries: Beginning at 6th level, you can alter your {@filter Infusions|optionalfeatures|feature type=LLAART:INF} on the fly. Over the course of a short rest, you can use tinker's tools to replace one of your Infusions Known with another Infusion of your choice or to learn to replicate one magic item you can touch. At the end of the short rest, you can imbue your new Infusion in an object you touch. If it requires attunement, you can follow the normal rules for attuning to your Infusions.
Once you replace one of your Infusions Known in this way you must finish a long rest before you can do so again.

classFeature.name: Tool Expertise
entries: There are few who can match an artificer's innate talent with their tools of choice. Starting at 6th level, whenever you make an ability check that uses a tool with which you are proficient, you can add double your proficiency bonus to your roll.

classFeature.name: Flash of Genius
entries: Beginning at 7th level, your analytical mind can offer potent insights and suggestions at a moment's notice. As a reaction, when you, or another creature you can see within 30 feet, makes an ability check or a saving throw, you can add your Intelligence modifier (minimum of +1) to the result of the roll.
You can use this feature a number of times equal to your Intelligence modifier (minimum of once), and you regain all expended uses when you finish a long rest.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 8th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Specialization Feature
entries: At 9th level, you gain a feature granted by your Specialization.

classFeature.name: Magic Item Mastery (4)
entries: You have gained a deep understanding of the inner workings of magic items, allowing you greater use of them. Starting at 10th level, you can attune to up to four magic items at once.
The number of magic items you can attune to at one time increases at 14th level (5 items) and at 18th level (6 items).

Finally, for you, crafting a magic item with a rarity of Common or Uncommon takes a quarter of the normal time and costs half the normal gold. When you reach 20th level, this bonus also applies to Rare and Very Rare magic items.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 12th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Arcane Breakthrough
entries: Beginning at 14th level, your expert understanding of magic items allows you to attune to any magic item regardless of any alignment, class, race, spell, or level requirements.

classFeature.name: Magic Item Mastery (5)
entries: You have gained a deep understanding of the inner workings of magic items, allowing you greater use of them. Starting at 14th level, you can attune to up to five magic items at once.

classFeature.name: Specialization Feature
entries: At 15th level, you gain a feature granted by your Specialization.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 16th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Magic Item Mastery (6)
entries: You have gained a deep understanding of the inner workings of magic items, allowing you greater use of them. Starting at 18th level, you can attune to up to six magic items at once.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 19th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Soul of Artifice
entries: You imbue a spark of your own essence in the magic items you bear. At 20th level, you gain a +1 bonus to all saving throws for each magic item you are attuned to. In addition, if you are reduced to 0 hit points but not killed outright, you can choose to end your attunement to one magic item or Infusion, causing you to drop to 1 hit point instead of 0.
Moreover, if you are killed, any object that bears one of your Infusions counts as part of your body for the purposes of any spell that would bring you back to life.

subclassFeature.name: Gunsmith
entries: You have dedicated your great intellect to the development of a one-of-a-kind weapon of war, the Arcane Firearm. Marked by this signature weapon, you enter the fray with the swagger and guile only found in one kind of Artificer, the Gunsmith.

subclassFeature.name: Tools of the Trade
entries: {@i 1st-level Gunsmith feature}
You gain proficiency {@item smith's tools|phb}. If you are already proficient with smith's tools, you instead gain proficiency with another set of {@item artisan's tools|phb} of your choice.

subclassFeature.name: Arcane Firearm
entries: {@i 1st-level Gunsmith feature}

You have crafted for yourself a unique magical firearm. At the end of a long rest, you can use smith's tools to craft an Arcane Firearm. It is a martial weapon with the loading, two-handed, and ranged (80/320) properties. You use your Intelligence, instead of your Dexterity, for its attack and damage rolls, and you gain proficiency with it. On hit, the Arcane Firearm deals piercing damage equal to {@dice 1d10} + your Intelligence modifier.
Your Arcane Firearm can bear one of your Infusions so long as it meets the prerequisite of that Infusion.
You can only have one Arcane Firearm at a time. Creating another Arcane Firearm renders that magic of the first inert.

subclassFeature.name: Gunsmith Spells
entries: {@i 2nd-level Gunsmith feature}
You learn certain spells at the Artificer levels noted in the table below. These don't count against your total number of Spells Known and cannot be switched upon gaining a level.

subclassFeature.name: Modular Firearm
entries: {@i 3rd-level Gunsmith feature}

Your Arcane Firearm is modular so you can adjust it to best meet the challenges at hand. You learn two of these Arcane Upgrades from the {@filter Arcane Upgrades|optionalfeatures|feature type=LLAART:GUN} list. When you gain an Artificer level you can replace one Arcane Upgrade you know with another Arcane Upgrade of your choice.
Over the course of 10 minutes, which can be during a short or long rest, you can use smith's tools to modify your Arcane Firearm with the benefits of one Arcane Upgrade you know.
You learn one additional Arcane Upgrade of your choice when you reach 5th level, and again at 9th and 15th level.

subclassFeature.name: Extra Attack
entries: {@i 5th-level Gunsmith feature}
Your skill in battle has grown. You can attack twice, instead of once, whenever you take the {@action Attack} action on your turn.
Moreover, your attacks with your Arcane Firearm count as magical for the sake of overcoming resistance and immunity.

subclassFeature.name: Overcharge
entries: {@i 9th-level Gunsmith feature}

You can imbue your Arcane Firearm's attacks with additional magic power. When you hit a target with an Arcane Firearm attack, you can expend a spell slot to cause that attack to deal bonus force damage to the target. This bonus force damage is {@damage 2d6} for a 1st-level spell slot, plus an additional {@damage 1d6} force damage for each slot level above 1st.
In addition, your Arcane Firearm can be modified with two Arcane Upgrades at one time.

subclassFeature.name: Quickdraw
entries: {@i 15th-level Gunsmith feature}
You always seem to shoot first. When you roll initiative, so long as you are not surprised, you can make a single attack with your Arcane Firearm before any other creatures act.
Finally, your Arcane Firearm can be modified with three Arcane Upgrades at one time.

subclassFeature.name: Agent
entries: While most artificers use their wondrous intellect to innovate and create, those known as Agents focus their considerable minds on hunting down information, objects, and most often, other creatures. Rivaling the great hunters of the wilderness, these Artificers leverage their wondrous Infusions and magic abilities in the pursuit of their current quarry.

subclassFeature.name: Tools of the Trade
entries: {@i 1st-level Agent feature}

You gain proficiency with {@filter martial weapons|items|source=phb|category=basic|type=martial weapon} and {@item smith's tools|phb}. If you are already proficient with smith's tools, you instead gain proficiency with another set of {@item artisan's tools|phb} of your choice.

subclassFeature.name: Seeking Sight
entries: {@i 1st-level Agent feature}

You have crafted a wondrous creation to aid you in pursuing your foes. Over the course of 1 hour, which can be during a short or long rest, you can use a set of tools to craft a Tiny object to aid you. You can only have one such object.

When wearing this object, most often over one or both eyes, you can use a bonus action to place an Arcane Mark on a creature or object that you can see within 60 feet. The Mark grants you the following benefits against the Marked target:

items: Whenever you make a Wisdom (Perception) or Wisdom (Survival) check related to it you gain a bonus to the roll equal to your Intelligence modifier (minimum of +1).
You can use Intelligence, in place of Strength or Dexterity, for weapon attack and damage rolls against your target, so long as that weapon bears one of your Infusions.
You always know the direction and distance to the target so long as you are on the same plane of existence.

entries: This Mark lasts for 1 hour, but ends early when you Mark another target or if you use your bonus action to end it. If the Mark is slain, you can use a reaction to Mark another target of your choice that you can see within range of this feature.

You can use this feature a number of times equal to your Intelligence modifier (minimum of once), and you regain all expended uses each time you finish a long rest. If you have no uses left, you can expend a spell slot to use this feature again.

subclassFeature.name: Agent Spells
entries: {@i 2nd-level Agent feature}
You learn certain spells at the Artificer levels noted in the table below. These don't count against your total number of Spells Known and cannot be switched upon gaining a level.

subclassFeature.name: Arcane Restraints
entries: {@i 3rd-level Agent feature}

You use wondrous inventions to enhance your ability to hunt, track, and capture your target. Once per turn when you hit your Mark with a weapon bearing your Infusions, you can force the target to make a Strength saving throw. On a failed save, the target is {@condition restrained}, and your Mark instantly ends.

As an action, the target, or another creature within 5 feet of it, can make a Strength check against your Spell save DC, ending the {@condition restrained} condition on your target on a success. This condition also ends if the target takes any damage.

subclassFeature.name: Enhanced Sight
entries: {@i 5th-level Agent feature}
Your Seeking Sight grants you wondrous insights into the targets that you Mark. When you Mark a target you instantly learn one of the following characteristics of your choice:

items: Its spellcasting modifier and the level of its highest spell.
Its creature type, alignment, and one language it speaks.
Its civilization of origin and approximate age.

subclassFeature.name: Extra Attack
entries: {@i 5th-level Agent feature}
You can attack twice, instead of once, whenever you take the Attack action on your turn. Moreover, you can cast one of your Artificer cantrips in place of one of these attacks.

subclassFeature.name: Defensive Maneuvers
entries: {@i 9th-level Agent feature}
Your analysis of your chosen foe allows you to better defend yourself against them. You gain the following new reactions:

items: When your Mark targets you with an attack that you can see, you can use your reaction to add your Intelligence modifier to your Armor Class against that attack.

If you Mark misses you with a melee attack you can use your reaction to force it to make a Dexterity saving throw against your Spell save DC. On a failed save, it is knocked {@condition prone} or {@condition grappled} by you (your choice). You must have a free hand in order to grapple a target with this feature.

subclassFeature.name: Master Agent
entries: {@i 15th-level Agent feature}

Your wondrous mind allows you to predict the actions of your enemies. Your Mark has disadvantage on any attack roll that it makes against you, and it has disadvantage on the first saving throw you force it to make on each of your turns.

subclassFeature.name: Mechanic
entries: Artificers known as Mechanics develop their obsession with arcane motors to construct wondrous mechanical vehicles. Donning a signature protective Mechanic's Coat, Mechanic Artificers will face any challenge as they design, construct, and improve their wondrous motorized Autocycle.

subclassFeature.name: Tools of the Trade
entries: {@i 1st-level Mechanic feature}

You gain proficiency with {@item smith's tools|phb} and land vehicles. If you are already proficient with smith's tools or land vehicles, you instead gain proficiency with another set of {@item artisan's tools|phb} of your choice.

subclassFeature.name: Mechanic's Coat
entries: {@i 1st-level Mechanic feature}

You have crafted the signature coat of a Mechanic to protect you from the hazards of your motorized inventions. Over the course of 1-hour, you can craft a Mechanic's Coat, which is sized to fit you and can be worn over light or medium armor.
While wearing your Coat you gain the following benefits:

items: Once per turn when you take bludgeoning, fire, piercing, thunder, or slashing damage, you can reduce the damage by your Intelligence modifier (minimum of 1 damage).
Your Coat can store a number of tools, weapons, and Tiny objects equal to your Intelligence modifier. You can draw and stow these objects as a free action on your turn.
If you are riding a vehicle while wearing your Coat, you cannot be knocked from the vehicle against your will.
Your Coat can bear one Infusion for armor or a cloak.

subclassFeature.name: Mechanic Spells
entries: {@i 2nd-level Mechanic feature}
You learn certain spells at the Artificer levels noted in the table below. These don't count against your total number of Spells Known and cannot be switched upon gaining a level.

subclassFeature.name: Autocycle
entries: {@i 3rd-level Mechanic feature}

Your obsession with motorized machinery has borne fruit in the construction of an {@creature Autocycle|LLAART|Autocycle}. It is a Medium vehicle with an appearance of your choosing, but its appearance has no effect on its statistics. It can be used as a mount by you, and while you are mounted on it, it shares your initiative, you can use its speed in place of your own, and you can use an action to use one of the actions from the {@creature Autocycle|LLAART|Autocycle} stat block.
Your {@creature Autocycle|LLAART|Autocycle} uses the stat block which uses your proficiency bonus (PB), Intelligence modifier (INT), and your Artificer Spell save DC in several places.

Your {@creature Autocycle|LLAART|Autocycle} can be used as a spellcasting focus for your Artificer spells while you ride it. It can also bear one Infusion normally meant for boots (wheels) or armor (chassis).

You can use tinker's or smith's tools to repair any damage to your {@creature Autocycle|LLAART|Autocycle}. For every 10 minutes you spend on repairs, your {@creature Autocycle|LLAART|Autocycle} regains hit points equal to your Artificer level.

If your {@creature Autocycle|LLAART|Autocycle} is destroyed, you can construct another during the course of a long rest, so long as you have access to tinkerâ€™s or smith's tools and enough scrap materials. You can only have one {@creature Autocycle|LLAART|Autocycle} at a time, and constructing a second causes any previous Autocycles to fall into disrepair.

subclassFeature.name: Afterburn
entries: {@i 5th-level Mechanic feature}

Once per turn, when you move within 5 feet of a creature while riding your {@creature Autocycle|LLAART|Autocycle}, you can force that creature to make a Dexterity saving throw. On a failure, it takes fire damage equal to {@damage 1d10} + your Intelligence modifier.

subclassFeature.name: Improved Autocycle
entries: {@i 5th-level Mechanic feature}
You are accustomed to fighting while riding your {@creature Autocycle|LLAART|Autocycle}. You gain the following benefits while riding your Autocycle:

items: When you cast a spell of 1st-level or higher with a target of self, your {@creature Autocycle|LLAART|Autocycle} also gains the benefits of the spell.
When your {@creature Autocycle|LLAART|Autocycle} is attacked, you can use a reaction to redirect the attack, causing you to be the attack's target.
Your {@creature Autocycle|LLAART|Autocycle} can bear two Medium creatures or three Small creatures, and its cargo capacity becomes 100 lb.
Riders can complete a short rest while mounted on your {@creature Autocycle|LLAART|Autocycle} so long as they do not take any damage, make no saving throws, and are traveling at a normal pace.

subclassFeature.name: Expert Rider
entries: {@i 9th-level Mechanic feature}

You can easily maneuver the {@creature Autocycle|LLAART|Autocycle} in any environment. While you are mounted on your {@creature Autocycle|LLAART|Autocycle}, its movement ignores difficult terrain imposed by magical and mundane effects, and opportunity attacks that target your {@creature Autocycle|LLAART|Autocycle}, and any creatures mounted on it, are made at disadvantage.

Also, when you move within 5 feet of a friendly creature while mounted on your {@creature Autocycle|LLAART|Autocycle}, it can use its reaction to mount your {@creature Autocycle|LLAART|Autocycle} behind you so long as there is room.

subclassFeature.name: Master Mechanic
entries: {@i 15th-level Mechanic feature}

Your {@creature Autocycle|LLAART|Autocycle} gains a flying speed equal to its movement speed, and it can hover. Your {@creature Autocycle|LLAART|Autocycle} and its riders also cannot be targeted by opportunity attacks while moving.
Moreover, your Afterburn feature deals fire damage equal to {@dice 2d10} + your Intelligence modifier.

subclassFeature.name: Alchemist
entries: Alchemy is a delicate art, tip the ratio of ingredients too far out of line and the effects could be disastrous. Alchemists are experts at combining exotic reagents to produce a variety of materials and effects. From healing droughts that can heal a wound in moments, to sticky goo that explodes when it comes in contact with flame. With the right reagents and a bit of luck, Alchemists use their wondrous Elixirs to give life to their allies and leech it away from their foes.

subclassFeature.name: Tools of the Trade
entries: {@i 1st-level Alchemist feature}

You gain proficiency with {@item alchemist's supplies|phb}. If you are already proficient with alchemist's supplies, you instead gain proficiency with another set of {@item artisan's tools|phb} of your choice.

Moreover, while you have access to alchemist's supplies, you can use your action to cast the {@spell acid splash|WMPS} cantrip, using Intelligence as your spellcasting modifier. When you gain the Spellcasting feature, {@spell acid splash|WMPS} counts as an artificer spell for you, but doesn't count against your total Cantrips Known.

subclassFeature.name: Homunculus
entries: {@i 1st-level Alchemist feature}

Your alchemical experimentation has yielded for you a loyal Homunculus Servant. You determine its appearance, but its appearance has no effect on its abilities. It is friendly to you and your companions, and it obeys your commands to the best of its ability. It uses the {@creature Homunculus Servant|LLAART} stat block, which uses your proficiency bonus (PB) in several places.

In combat, your Homunculus acts during your turn. It can move and use its reaction on its own, but the only action it takes is the {@action Dodge} action unless you use a bonus action to command it to take an action from its stat block, or another action. If you are {@condition incapacitated}, your Homunculus can take any action it chooses. If you die, your Homunculus turns to ash after a number of minutes equal to your artificer level.
If your Homunculus has died within the last hour, you can touch it with alchemist's supplies and expend a spell slot of 1st-level or higher to return to life at its maximum hit points.
At the end of a long rest, you can make a new Homunculus Servant using your alchemist's supplies. If you already have a Homunculus from this feature, the first one turns to ash.

subclassFeature.name: Alchemist Spells
entries: {@i 2nd-level Alchemist feature}
You learn certain spells at the artificer levels noted in the table below. These don't count against your total number of Spells Known and can't be switched upon gaining a level.

subclassFeature.name: Alchemical Elixirs
entries: {@i 3rd-level Alchemist feature}
As your knowledge of alchemy has grown, you have learned to create potent Elixirs that mimic certain spell effects:

entries.name: Elixir Infusion
entries: Your total number of Infusions Known increases by one, but this extra Infusion must be from the list of {@filter Elixir Infusions|optionalfeatures|feature type=LLAART:ALC}.

Your total number of Infusions Known increases by one again 9th level and at 15th level in this class. Both of these additional Infusions must also be chosen from the list of Elixir Infusions at the end of this Specialization.

entries.name: Creating an Elixir
entries: At the end of each long rest, you can use alchemist's supplies to create individual Tiny vials that contain a copy of each Elixir you know, without expending a spell slot. Elixirs produce the effect of their spell at its lowest level and become unusable at the end of your next long rest.
As an action, you can create another vial of an Elixir you know by expending the spell slot listed in its description. An Elixir can be used as part of the same action you create it.

entries.name: Using an Elixir
entries: As an action, any creature can drink an Elixir, administer an Elixir to a creature within its reach, or throw an Elixir at a point within 30 feet. When thrown, an Elixir produces its spell effect at the point of impact. If an Elixir spell requires concentration, the creature that drinks it must concentrate on the effect. Your Elixir spells use your artificer spell save DC and spellcasting modifier.

For example, if you learn the create minor elixir Infusion and choose {@spell grease} and {@spell sleep}, at the end of each long rest you prepare an elixir of grease, and an elixir of sleep. Creatures can then use these Elixirs to produce the spell effects.

subclassFeature.name: Potent Potions
entries: {@i 5th-level Alchemist feature}

Whenever one of your Elixirs or an artificer spell cast by you deals acid, fire, necrotic, or poison damage, or restores hit points to a creature, you can add your Intelligence modifier (minimum of +1) to one of the damage or healing rolls.

subclassFeature.name: Restorative Reagents
entries: {@i 9th-level Alchemist feature}

You include revitalizing additives in all the Elixirs you create. When a creature uses one of your Elixirs on themselves or restores a creature's hit points with one, the target of the Elixir gains temporary hit points equal to your artificer level.

subclassFeature.name: Master Alchemist
entries: {@i 15th-level Alchemist feature}
You have become a master among Alchemist artificers. You gain resistance to both acid and poison damage, and you are immune to the {@condition poisoned} condition.
Moreover, you can create a copy of any Elixir you know as a bonus action on your turn. You must still expend a spell slot and follow all other rules for creating an Alchemical Elixir.

subclassFeature.name: Armorer
entries: Of all the Specializations that an artificer can pursue, that of the Armorer is the most defensively-minded. With a focus on becoming a bastion of magics and metal, Armorers modify a set of armor to function as their second skin. They focus their signature magic through this armor to unleash potent attacks and generate formidable arcane defenses. An Armorer views their armor as an extension of their body, and as they refine their magical abilities, inventor and armor become one.

subclassFeature.name: Tools of the Trade
entries: {@i 1st-level Armorer feature}

You gain proficiency with {@item smith's tools|phb} and {@item leatherworker's tools|phb}. If you are already proficient with smith's or leatherworker's tools, you instead gain proficiency with another set of {@item artisan's tools|phb} of your choice.

subclassFeature.name: Arcane Gauntlet
entries: {@i 1st-level Armorer feature}

You can forge for yourself a wondrous weapon of war known as an Arcane Gauntlet. At the end of a long rest, you can use smith's tools to create an Arcane Gauntlet, choosing for it to be a Lightning Cannon or Thunder Gauntlet. It is a simple weapon only usable by you, and you use your Intelligence, in place of Strength or Dexterity, for its attack and damage rolls.
You can only have one Arcane Gauntlet at a time. Creating a second causes the magic of the first to immediately dispel.

entries.name: Lightning Cannon
entries: Your Arcane Gauntlet gains the ranged (90/300) property. On hit, it deals {@damage 1d6} lightning damage, and once per turn, when you hit with a Lightning Cannon attack, you can cause it to deal an additional {@damage 1d6} lightning damage.

entries.name: Thunder Gauntlet
entries: Your Arcane Gauntlet remains a melee weapon. On hit, it deals {@damage 1d8} thunder damage, and once per turn, you can give a creature hit by this Gauntlet disadvantage on attack rolls against targets other than you until the start of your next turn.

subclassFeature.name: Armorer Spells
entries: {@i 2nd-level Armorer feature}
You learn certain spells at the artificer levels noted in the table below. These don't count against your total number of Spells Known and can't be switched upon gaining a level.

subclassFeature.name: Arcane Armor
entries: {@i 3rd-level Armorer feature}

You expand the magic of your Arcane Gauntlet to encompass a full suit of armor. At the end of a long rest, you can use your smith's tools to transform a set of armor into Arcane Armor. This armor incorporates your Arcane Gauntlet, is only usable by you, and while wearing it you gain the following benefits:

items: If the set of armor normally has a Strength requirement, your Arcane Armor lacks this requirement for you.
You can use your Arcane Armor as a spellcasting focus.
Your Arcane Armor attaches to you and can't be removed against your will. It expands to cover your entire body, and functionally replaces any missing limbs or body parts.
You can don or doff your Arcane Armor as an action, and can retract or deploy the helmet as a bonus action.
You can use a bonus action to grant yourself temporary hit points equal to your Intelligence modifier (minimum of 1).

subclassFeature.name: Armorer Adept
entries: {@i 5th-level Armorer feature}
You can use magical armor as Arcane Armor. Though, any innate magical bonuses to Armor Class from magic armor, Infusions, or other features don't stack. You must choose one.
Finally, you can attack twice, instead of once, whenever you take the Attack action on your turn, and you can cast one of your artificer cantrips in place of one of your attacks.

subclassFeature.name: Modular Armor
entries: {@i 9th-level Armorer feature}
Your Arcane Armor counts as multiple items for the purpose of your Infusions: armor (the chest piece), boots, helmet, and the gauntlets (weapon), and each item can bear one Infusion.
Also, your number of Infusions Known increases by 2, but these extra Infusions must be applied to your Arcane Armor.

subclassFeature.name: Master Armorer
entries: {@i 15th-level Armorer feature}
You have become a master of Armorer artifice. You gain the benefits listed below while wearing your Arcane Armor:

items: You gain a flying speed equal to your walking speed.
You adjust your Arcane Armor so that you have access to both your Lightning Launcher and Thunder Gauntlet.
Your Lightning Launcher now deals {@dice 2d6} damage, and your Thunder Gauntlet now deals {@dice 2d8} damage.

subclassFeature.name: Battle Smith
entries: A combination of protector and medic, Battle Smith artificers are experts at defending others and repairing both material and personnel. To aid in their work, Battle Smiths construct and modify their Steel Defender, a one-of-a-kind companion.

subclassFeature.name: Tools of the Trade
entries: {@i 1st-level Battle Smith feature}

You gain proficiency with {@item smith's tools|phb} and in {@item mason's tools|phb}. If you are proficient in smith's or mason's tools, you gain proficiency in another set of {@item artisan's tools|phb} of your choice.

entries.name: Construct and Creator
entries: Battle Smiths are famous for their Steel Defenders, which are as unique as the artificers that created them. Some resemble polished and sophisticated servants, while others serve as battlefield mounts.

subclassFeature.name: Steel Defender
entries: {@i 1st-level Battle Smith feature}

You have created for yourself a faithful construct, known as a Steel Defender. It is friendly to you and your allies and obeys your orders. Your Steel Defender's game statistics are found in the Steel Defender stat block, which uses your proficiency bonus (PB) in multiple places.

In combat, your Steel Defender acts during your turn. It can move and use its reaction on its own, but it only uses the {@action Dodge} action on its turn unless you use your bonus action to order it to take an action in its stat block, or another action. If you are {@condition incapacitated}, your Steel Defender acts on its own.
If your Steel Defender has died within the last hour, you can use your action to touch it with your smith's tools and expend an artificer spell slot to return it to life with its maximum hit points.
At the end of a long rest, you can magically create a new Steel Defender with your smith's tools. When you do so, any previous Steel Defenders are immediately rendered inert.
Upon its creation, you choose the shape of your Steel Defender, which can affect its abilities in and out of combat:

items: {@creature Steel Defender (Humanoid)|LLAART|Humanoid}. Your Steel Defender is the size of a Medium humanoid creature. It is proficient with shields, and it has humanoid hands that it can use to perform basic tasks.

{@creature Steel Defender (Quadruped)|LLAART|Quadruped}. Your Steel Defender resembles a Large beast of your choice. Its speed increases by 10 feet, and it can be ridden as a mount by you as if it was a trained mount.

subclassFeature.name: Battle Smith Spells
entries: {@i 2nd-level Battle Smith feature}
You learn certain spells at the artificer levels noted in the table below. These don't count against your total number of Spells Known and can't be switched upon gaining a level.

rows: {@spell circle of power}, {@spell mass cure wounds|WMPS}

subclassFeature.name: Battle Ready
entries: {@i 3rd-level Battle Smith feature}

You have trained to stand alongside your Steel Defender in battle. You can use your Intelligence in place of Strength or Dexterity for attack and damage rolls you make with magic weapons, or any weapon that bears one of your Infusions.

subclassFeature.name: Infusion Bearer
entries: {@i 5th-level Battle Smith feature}

You have designed your Steel Defender to bear your most potent Infusions. Your Steel Defender can bear any Infusion that is meant for boots, cloaks, gauntlets, helms, or suits of armor. Though, it can only bear one Infusion at a time.

subclassFeature.name: Minor Upgrade
entries: {@i 5th-level Battle Smith feature}
You have improved the offensive capabilities of your Steel Defender. Choose one of the Minor Upgrades below:

entries.name: Minor Arcanum
entries: You imbue your Steel Defender with a 1st-level artificer spell with a casting time of one action. As a bonus action, you can order your Steel Defender to cast the imbued spell at 1st-level, using your spellcasting modifier. Your Steel Defender has a number of charges of the spell equal to your Intelligence modifier (minimum of 1), and it regains all expended charges when you finish a long rest.

entries.name: Martial Offense
entries: The damage of your Steel Defender's Rend becomes {@dice 1d10}, and when you command it to take the Rend action it can make two Rend attacks instead of one. It can replace either Rend attack with a grapple or shove.

subclassFeature.name: Adjustable Upgrades
entries: {@i 9th-level Battle Smith feature}

You can adjust your Steel Defender's Upgrades to face the challenges at hand. Each time you finish a long rest, you can use your smith's tools to replace one of your Steel Defender's Upgrades with another Upgrade gained at the same level.

subclassFeature.name: Greater Upgrade
entries: {@i 9th-level Battle Smith feature}
You can imbue your Steel Defender with wondrous abilities and features. Choose one of the Greater Upgrades below:

entries.name: Limited Sentience
entries: You improve the cognitive abilities of your Steel Defender. Its Intelligence score becomes a 10. It also gains proficiency with a set of tools of your choice and learns to speak, read, and write two languages of your choice.

entries.name: Modular Construction
entries: Your Steel Defender can bear up to two Infusions, though the Infusions must be meant for different types of objects. For example, your Steel Defender could be infused with an Infusion meant for a suit of armor and an Infusion meant for a helm, but not two Infusions that are both meant to be used on suits of armor.

entries.name: Reinforced Plating
entries: You improve the structure of your Steel Defender. It gains resistance to bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing damage from all non-magical attacks.

subclassFeature.name: Masterwork Upgrade
entries: {@i 15th-level Battle Smith feature}
You imbue your Steel Defender with wondrous abilities and powers. Choose one of the Masterwork Upgrades below:

entries.name: Arcane Ward
entries: Creatures of your choice within 15 feet of your Steel Defender are resistant to damage from spells.

entries.name: Self-Destruct
entries: You embed a powerful arcane explosive in your Steel Defender. As a bonus action, you can order your Steel Defender to self-destruct, destroying itself and forcing creatures within 20 feet to make a Dexterity saving throw. Creatures take force damage equal to your Steel Defenders remaining Hit Dice on a failed save, or half as much damage on a success. Once this feature is used, your Steel Defender cannot be revived until the end of your next long rest.

entries.name: Major Arcanum
entries: You imbue your Steel Defender with a 3rd-level artificer spell with a casting time of one action. As a bonus action, you can order your Steel Defender to cast the imbued spell at 3rd-level, using your spellcasting modifier.
Your Steel Defender has a number of charges of the spell equal to your Intelligence modifier (minimum of 1), and it regains all expended charges when you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Reanimator
entries: Most artificers focus their creativity on mechanical or arcane inventions, but those known as Reanimators use their unique abilities to raise their defeated enemies as Thralls. Instead of improving themselves, they put everything utilizing the abilities of that their Thralls had in life, now in undeath.

subclassFeature.name: Tools of the Trade
entries: {@i 1st-level Reanimator feature}

You gain proficiency in Nature and {@item leatherworker's tools|phb}. If you're already proficient with leatherworker's tools, you instead gain proficiency with another set of {@item artisan's tools|phb} of your choice.

subclassFeature.name: Reanimated Thrall
entries: {@i 1st-level Reanimator feature}

You can restore a facsimile of life to your slain foes. Over the course of 1 minute, you can perform a special ritual where you use leatherworker's tools on one creature you can touch that has died within the last minute. At the end of this ritual, the target rises as a Thrall as if it had completed a long rest.

The creatures you can reanimate as Thralls are limited by your Artificer level, as shown in the Max. CR column of the Potential Thralls table below. You can only reanimate Beasts and Monstrosities as Thralls, but you can learn to reanimate other creature types as you gain levels in this class.
Your Thrall uses the stat block it had in life, but it gains the Undead creature type in addition to its original type, it has no Hit Dice, and it gains no benefits from short or long rests.

Your Thrall is mindless and obeys your orders completely to the best of its abilities. In combat, it acts on your turn. It can move and use its reaction on its own, but it will only take the {@action Dodge} action on its turn unless you use your bonus action to command it to take an action from its stat block or another combat action. If you are {@condition incapacitated}, your Thrall will act on its own to defend itself, but it will take no further actions.
Once your Thrall is slain, it cannot be raised as a Thrall again. If you raise a second Thrall while another Thrall lives, your previous Thrall falls to 0 hit points and instantly dies.

subclassFeature.name: Reanimator Spells
entries: {@i 2nd-level Reanimator feature}
You learn certain spells at the artificer levels noted in the table below. These don't count against your total number of Spells Known and can't be switched upon gaining a level.

subclassFeature.name: Greater Reanimations
entries: {@i 3rd-level Reanimator feature}

As your knowledge of reanimation grows, you learn to create Thralls from more diverse and powerful creatures. Choose a creature type from the following, which you can reanimate as a Thrall as part of your Reanimated Thrall feature: Ooze, Plant, or Undead.

subclassFeature.name: Extra Attack
entries: {@i 5th-level Reanimator feature}

You can attack twice, instead of once, whenever you take the {@action Attack} action on your turn. Moreover, whenever you take the Attack action, you can command your Thrall to make on attack from its stat block in place of one of your attacks.

subclassFeature.name: Advanced Reanimations
entries: {@i 9th-level Reanimator feature}

You can raise some of the most powerful mortal creatures in existence to serve you as Thralls. Choose one creature type from the following, which you can reanimate as a Thrall as part of your Reanimated Thrall feature: Aberration, Dragon, or Giant.

subclassFeature.name: Masterwork Thrall
entries: {@i 15th-level Reanimator feature}

You can keep your Thralls alive so long as your power lasts. When your Thrall is reduced to 0 hit points, but not killed outright, you can use a reaction and spend a spell slot of 1st-level or higher to grant your Thrall a number of hit points equal to 10 times the level of the spell slot you spend as part of the reaction.

subclassFeature.name: Venomist
entries: Fascinated by toxins, venoms, and poisons that are produced by monsters and animals, Venomists are Artificers who learn to reproduce these potent poisons for their own personal use. Adept at harvesting and weaponizing the venom of monsters, these Artificers can also create their own signature poisons.

subclassFeature.name: Tools of the Trade
entries: {@i 1st-level Venomist feature}

You gain proficiency with blow guns and {@item poisoner's kit|phb}. If you're already proficient with poisoner's kits, you instead gain proficiency with another set of {@item artisan's tools|phb} of your choice.
Moreover, whenever you make a poisoner's kit check and you have at least 10 minutes to complete the check, you can treat a roll of 9 or lower on the d20 as a 10.

subclassFeature.name: Poisoner Adept
entries: {@i 1st-level Venomist feature}

You have spent a great deal of time working with, creating, and weaponizing various poisons. You learn the {@spell poison spray|WMPS} cantrip, but it doesn't count against your number of cantrips known. When you cast {@spell poison spray|WMPS} using a poisoner's kit as the spellcasting focus and target a creature within 5 feet of you, it has disadvantage on its Constitution saving throw.
In addition, you can take the {@action Use an Object} action as a bonus action on each of your turns. However, you can only use it to use a poisoner's kit or to apply a vial of poison.
Finally, any poisons that you craft use your Artificer Spell save DC in place of the normal DC for that poison.

subclassFeature.name: Venomist Spells
entries: {@i 2nd-level Venomist feature}
You learn certain spells at the artificer levels noted in the table below. These don't count against your total number of Spells Known and can't be switched upon gaining a level.

rows: {@spell detect poison and disease}, {@spell ray of sickness}
{@spell protection from poison}, {@spell ray of enfeeblement}

subclassFeature.name: Infused Poisons
entries: {@i 3rd-level Venomist feature}
As your knowledge of poisons has grown, you have learned to create your own signature poisons as detailed below:
{@b Venomist Infusions.} Your number of Infusions Known increases by one, but the extra Infusion must be from the list of {@filter Venomist Infusions|optionalfeatures|feature type=LLAART:VEN}.

Your total number of Infusions Known increases by one again at 9th level, and again at 15th level in this class. Both of these additional Infusions must also be chosen from the list of Venomist Infusions.

{@b Infusing a Poison.} At the end of each long rest, you can use a poisoner's kit to create one vial of each Infused Poison you know without expending a spell slot. Any Infused Poisons you create lose their potency at the end of your next long rest.
As an action, you can use a poisoner's kit to create another vial of one Infused Poison that you know from a Venomist Infusion by expending the spell slot listed in its description.

subclassFeature.name: Potent Venom
entries: {@i 5th-level Venomist feature}
Whenever one of your poisons or an Artificer spell cast by you deals acid, necrotic, or poison damage, you can add your Intelligence modifier (minimum of +1) to one damage roll.

subclassFeature.name: Inoculation
entries: {@i 9th-level Venomist feature}
Your work with poisons of all kinds has made you especially resistant to their effects. You gain immunity to the {@condition poisoned} condition and gain resistance to acid and poison damage.

subclassFeature.name: Deadly Toxins
entries: {@i 15th-level Venomist feature}
Whenever you, or a poison that you have created deals acid, poison, or necrotic damage, you can treat a roll of 1 or 2 on any of its damage dice as a 3.

subclassFeature.name: Valkyrie
entries: Valkyries are masters of revolutionary medicine. These Artificers use a combination of alchemy and machinery to replicate pre-existing magic and keep their patients alive. Some use their research to improve lifespans and cure diseases, while others have obsessions with inhumane medical experiements.

subclassFeature.name: Tools of the Trade
entries: {@i 1st-level Valkyrie feature}
You gain proficiency with {@item herbalism kit|phb}. If you're already proficient with a herbalism kit, you instead gain proficiency with another set of {@item artisan's tools|phb} of your choice.

subclassFeature.name: Arcane Apparatus
entries: {@i 1st-level Valkyrie feature}

You build an Arcane Apparatus, a brass gauntlet usually strapped around the forearm. You use this apparatus to administer medicine, and can use it as an Artificer spellcasting focus, as long as you have another Artificer spellcasting focus on you.

Your Arcane Apparatus comes equipped with a short-range serum injection system typically called the Valkyrie (although your Artificer may have another name for it). As an action, you can expend one charge of the Valkyrie to heal a creature within 30 feet of you for {@dice 1d6}. You may also use it as a bonus action, though if you do, the healing you deliver is halved. You may only use your Valkyrie once per turn. You have an amount of charges equal to twice your Intelligence modifier, and regain all expended charges at the end of a long rest.
Your Valkyrie dice increases to {@dice 1d8} at 6th level, {@dice 1d10} at 10th level, and {@dice 1d12} at 16th level.
Additionally, you can use Intelligence instead of Wisdom for Medicine checks.

subclassFeature.name: Valkyrie Spells
entries: {@i 2nd-level Valkyrie feature}
You learn certain spells at the artificer levels noted in the table below. These don't count against your total number of Spells Known and can't be switched upon gaining a level.

rows: {@spell beacon of hope}, {@spell mass healing word|WMPS}

subclassFeature.name: Pick Me Ups
entries: {@i 3rd-level Valkyrie feature}

You've learned how to infuse a small dose of various medical grade drugs into your Arcane Apparatus. Your Arcane Apparatus now adds your Intelligence modifier to its dice when you heal a creature with it.
In addition, when you heal a creature using your Arcane Apparatus, you can impart one of the following effects until the start of your next turn:

items: {@b Painkillers.} Roll your Valkyrie die. The creature reduces damage they take by half of the number rolled (rounded up).
{@b Adrenaline Boost.} Roll your Valkyrie die. The creature increases their movement speed by a number equal to 5 times the number rolled.
{@b Steroids.} Roll your Valkyrie die. The creature deals additional damage with their melee weapon attacks equal to half the number rolled (rounded up).

subclassFeature.name: Surgical Shell
entries: {@i 5th-level Valkyrie feature}

Your restorative techniques include providing patients with extra layers of protection. Whenever you heal a creature with a spell, it gains temporary hit points equal to your proficiency bonus until the end of your next turn.
While a creature has these temporary hit points, you can treat that creature's space as the origin of your spells.

subclassFeature.name: Do No Harm
entries: {@i 9th-level Valkyrie feature}

The integration of your tools with your combat techniques allow you to better help your teammates. When an enemy you can see within 30 feet of you makes an attack against an allied creature, you can use your reaction to immediately use your Arcane Apparatus on them after the attack. You can use Do No Harm a number of times equal to your proficiency bonus, regaining all expended uses at the end of a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Medical Mastery
entries: {@i 15th-level Valkyrie feature}

You have learned the deepest secrets of your craft, giving your medicine unrivaled potency. Whenever you cast a single target healing spell or use your Arcane Apparatus, you can double the healing done. You may do this three times per long rest.

Additionally, you can add twice your proficiency bonus to Wisdom (Medicine) or Intelligence (Medicine) checks, and whenever you make a Wisdom (Medicine) or Intelligence (Medicine) check, you can treat a d20 roll of 7 or lower as an 8.

subclassFeature.name: Octoperior
entries: An artificer who specializes as an Octoperior uses a special harness which allows them to control additional tentacle-like arms. The arms extend the reach of their wearer and allow them to manipulate hazardous materials from a distance. Such artificers believe that such technology is the future, and seek for all to be augmented to strive for the next state of human evolution.

subclassFeature.name: Tools of the Trade
entries: {@i 1st-level Octoperior feature}
You gain proficiency with {@item smith's tools|phb}. If you're already proficient with smith's tools, you instead gain proficiency with another set of {@item artisan's tools|phb} of your choice.

subclassFeature.name: Mechanical Arms
entries: {@i 1st-level Octoperior feature}
You've constructed for yourself a harness which has four tentacle-like arms attached to it. The arms provide the following additional benefits:

items: You can control these mechanical arms as if they were your own arms, able to manipulate and hold objects and weapons as normal, but you cannot gain the benefit of using a shield held by these arms.
When you use these mechanical arms, their reach is 10 feet instead of 5 feet. This does not apply to attacks made with weapons other than your mechanical arm strikes.
Each mechanical arm can carry up to a number of pounds equal to 10 times your Artificer level.

Each of the mechanical arms counts as a simple melee weapon you can strike with while you aren't holding anything in it, and it deals {@dice 1d8} bludgeoning damage on a hit. In addition, your arms count as magical for the purposes of overcoming resistance and immunity to nonmagical damage.
The mechanical arms can't be removed from you against your will.
Your mechanical arms can grab into the sides of walls and climb, granting you a climb speed equal to your base walking speed.
Additionally, you can use Intelligence instead of Strength for the attack and damage rolls for your arm strikes.

subclassFeature.name: Octoperior Spells
entries: {@i 2nd-level Octoperior feature}
You learn certain spells at the artificer levels noted in the table below. These don't count against your total number of Spells Known and can't be switched upon gaining a level.

subclassFeature.name: Refined Control
entries: {@i 3rd-level Octoperior feature}

You've learned how to control your arms with more finesse and precision. You may now use these arms to make and maintain a grapple, using your Strength (Athletics) as per normal grappling. You can still only grapple one creature at a time with each mechanical arm.
In addition, you can do one of the following as an action on your turns:

items: {@b Battering Assault}. Your arms whirl out around you, striking creatures of your choice within reach of your arms and trying to knock them off balance. They must make a Strength saving throw or take {@dice 1d8} bludgeoning damage and be knocked {@condition prone}, taking half damage on a successful save and not being knocked {@condition prone}.

{@b Defensive Maneuvers}. Your arms take up defensive positions around you, preparing to rebuke any who would attack you. You gain +1 to your AC. In addition, when you are attacked and the attack misses, your arms turn the opponent's attack back against them. If the attack roll would hit the opponent, they take the damage instead. If it was a ranged attack, the arms throw the projectile back at the opponent but they only take half the damage.

{@b Entangling Arms}. Two of your mechanical arms lash out towards one creature within reach of your arms. The creature must make a Dexterity saving throw or be {@condition restrained} by your arms. The creature may attempt to break out using their action to make a Strength (Athletics) or Dexterity (Acrobatics) check (DC equal to your spell save DC). While they are {@condition restrained} within your arms, you cannot use the two arms grappling them for anything else until they are released. As a bonus action on your turn, you can squeeze them tightly and deal {@dice 1d8} bludgeoning damage.

entries.name: Grappling from a Distance
entries: Remember, a creature {@condition grappled} by you, no matter how far from your body, is able to attack whatever limb or Mechanical Arm you are using to grapple it. Attacks against your Mechanical Arms are treated as attacks against you.

subclassFeature.name: Extra Attack
entries: {@i 5th-level Octoperior feature}

You can attack twice, rather than once, whenever you take the {@action Attack} action on your turn. Moreover, you may substitute one of your attacks on your turn to use one of the options from Refined Control.

subclassFeature.name: Tentacle Upgrades
entries: {@i 9th-level Octoperior feature}

You've managed to directly connect your arms to your subconscious for greater control and have upgraded their reach. The reach for your tentacles increases by 5 additional feet, and their damage increases from {@dice 1d8} to {@dice 1d10} bludgeoning damage, which also increases the damage for the options in Refined Control. Additionally, you can use your mechanical arms to move or climb up to your movement speed each turn while you are unconscious.

subclassFeature.name: Superior Upgrades
entries: {@i 15th-level Octoperior feature}
Your Mechanical Arms gain the following additional benefits as your neural link with them is perfected:

items: You can use two of your mechanical arms to walk across the ground using your movement speed as long as the arms aren't holding anything, lifting yourself up to 5 feet off of the ground. Whenever you do so, you are unaffected by difficult terrain.

As a bonus action, you can throw a creature or item a mechanical arm of yours is holding or grappling by making a ranged attack roll at a target within 60 feet. You may use Intelligence for this attack roll. On a hit, the target takes {@dice 3d6} plus your Intelligence modifier magical bludgeoning damage, and must succeed on a Strength saving throw versus your Artificer Spell Save DC or fall {@condition prone}. Regardless if your attack hits or not, the item or creature being thrown takes the same {@dice 3d6} plus your Intelligence modifier magical bludgeoning damage and lands in an unoccupied space within 5 feet of the target. You can make this throwing attack a number of times equal to your proficiency bonus, and regain all uses of this feature on a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Forgewright
entries: While most artificers are primarily inventors that take up a life of adventure to test experiments in the field, those known as Forgewrights seek out battle for its own sake. Reveling in the thrill of combat, they combine their innovation with their skill as warriors to forge their signature Arcane Armament.

subclassFeature.name: Tools of the Trade
entries: {@i 1st-level Forgewright feature}

You gain proficiency with {@filter martial weapons|items|source=phb|category=basic|type=martial weapon} and {@item smith's tools|phb}. If you're already proficient with smith's tools, you instead gain proficiency with another set of {@item artisan's tools|phb} of your choice.

subclassFeature.name: Arcane Armament
entries: {@i 1st-level Forgewright feature}

Over the course of 1 hour, which can be during a short or long rest, you can use smith's tools to transform one melee weapon you touch into your Arcane Armament. You can only have one Arcane Armament at a time, and enchanting a second causes the magic of the first to end. While you wield your Arcane Armament, you gain the benefits below.

items: You can use your Intelligence, in place of Strength or Dexterity, for attack and damage rolls with the weapon.
The weapon gains both the thrown (20/60) and returning properties. After you make a thrown weapon attack with your Arcane Armament, it instantly returns to your hand.
It counts as a magical weapon if it was not already.

subclassFeature.name: Forgewright Spells
entries: {@i 2nd-level Forgewright feature}
You learn certain spells at the artificer levels noted in the table below. These don't count against your total number of Spells Known and can't be switched upon gaining a level.

subclassFeature.name: Forge of War
entries: {@i 3rd-level Forgewright feature}
Your signature artifice enhances the power of your weapon. Any weapon attacks you make with your Arcane Armament score a critical hit on a roll of 19 or 20 on the d20.
Also, your total number of Infusions Known increases by 1. However, this bonus Infusion must be applied to your Arcane Armament, and can be applied even if it was a magic weapon.
You may not apply the Enhanced Defense Infusion to any Arcane Armament in this way, however.

subclassFeature.name: Arcane Jolt
entries: {@i 5th-level Forgewright feature}

When you hit a target with your Arcane Armament you can expend a spell slot to deal additional force damage to the target. The extra damage is {@damage 2d6} for a 1st-level spell slot, plus {@damage 1d6} for each spell level higher than 1st, to a maximum of {@dice 6d6}.

subclassFeature.name: Extra Attack
entries: {@i 5th-level Forgewright feature}
You can attack twice, instead of once, whenever you take the {@action Attack} action on your turn.

subclassFeature.name: Improved Arcane Jolt
entries: The magic of your Arcane Armament empowers its strikes. Each time you hit a creature with a weapon attack with your Arcane Armament you deal an additional {@damage 1d6} force damage.
This force damage does not count against the maximum amount of damage you can deal with your Arcane Jolt feature.

subclassFeature.name: Master Forgewright
entries: {@i 15th-level Forgewright feature}

You have become a master among Forgewright artificers and can extend the power within your Arcane Armament to allies. As an action, you can hold aloft your Arcane Armament and choose a number of weapons equal to your Intelligence modifier (minimum of 1) within 30 feet, one of which can be your Arcane Armament. For the next minute these weapons deal an additional {@damage 1d6} force damage on hit.

Once you use this feature you must finish a long rest before you can use it again. If you have no uses of this feature left, you can expend an artificer spell slot of 3rd-level or higher to use this feature again.

subclassFeature.name: Wandslinger
entries: Wandslingers use their ingenuity and artistic minds to craft wondrous arcane weapons. What they lack in flexibility and subtlety, they make up for in overwhelming arcane firepower. Wandslingers are marked by their signature Arcane Sidearm. For some, these are intricately carved wands or staffs, and for others, they are expertly crafted runic iron cannons.

subclassFeature.name: Tools of the Trade
entries: {@i 1st-level Wandslinger feature}

You gain proficiency with {@item woodcarver's tools|phb}. If you are already proficient with woodcarver's tools, you instead gain proficiency with another set of {@item artisan's tools|phb} of your choice.

subclassFeature.name: Arcane Sidearm
entries: {@i 1st-level Wandslinger feature}

You have constructed for yourself a Wandslinger's signature weapon. At the end of a long rest, you can use woodcarver's tools to craft an Arcane Sidearm. It resembles a Tiny object of your choosing, though its appearance has no effect on its abilities. Many Wandslingers craft Sidearms that resemble delicate wands, ornate rods, or even eldritch cannons.

Your Arcane Sidearm is a simple weapon with the ranged (120/300) property, and you use your Intelligence, instead of your Dexterity, for its attack and damage rolls. On hit, it deals force damage equal to {@dice 1d10} + your Intelligence modifier.
When you gain the Spellcasting feature at 2nd level, your Arcane Sidearm can be used as a spellcasting focus by you.
You can only have one Arcane Sidearm at a time. Creating another Arcane Sidearm renders that magic of the first inert.

subclassFeature.name: Quickdraw
entries: {@i 1st-level Wandslinger feature}

You have honed your reflexes so that you can nearly always strike first. When you roll initiative and are not surprised or {@condition incapacitated}, you can use your reaction to make one attack with your Arcane Sidearm, or another magic wand, rod, or staff that you are holding before any other creatures act.

subclassFeature.name: Wandslinger Spells
entries: {@i 2nd-level Wandslinger feature}
You learn certain spells at the artificer levels noted in the table below. These don't count against your total number of Spells Known and can't be switched upon gaining a level.

rows: {@spell cone of cold}, {@spell wall of force}

subclassFeature.name: Arcane Duelist
entries: {@i 3rd-level Wandslinger feature}
You have begun to master the signature abilities of an arcane duelist. As a bonus action on each of your turns, you can use your Arcane Sidearm to use one of the abilities listed below.
If one of these abilities forces a creature to make a saving throw, it does so against your artificer Spell save DC.

entries.name: Shocking Burst
entries: Your Arcane Sidearm conjures a burst of lightning at a point you can see within 60 feet, forcing creatures within 5 feet to make a Dexterity saving throw. Creatures take {@damage 2d6} lightning damage on a failure, and half as much damage on a success.

entries.name: Thunderous Blast
entries: Your Arcane Sidearm emits a blast of magic in an adjacent 15-foot cone. Any creatures in that area must succeed on a Dexterity saving throw or take {@damage 2d6} thunder damage.
Any Large or smaller creature that fails this saving throw is also knocked back 10 feet away from you in a straight line.

entries.name: Wandslinger's Ward
entries: Your Arcane Sidearm produces a field that grants you, or a creature of your choice within 10 feet of you, temporary hit points equal to your Intelligence modifier (minimum of 1).

subclassFeature.name: Spell Slinger
entries: {@i 5th-level Wandslinger feature}

You wield your Arcane Sidearm with deadly skill. When you use your action to make an attack with your Arcane Sidearm, you can make two attacks instead of just one. These attacks can target two targets or the same target.
As you gain artificer levels, the number of Arcane Sidearm attacks you make as part of a single action increases: at 11th level (3), and 17th level (4).

subclassFeature.name: Expert Duelist
entries: {@i 9th-level Wandslinger feature}
The amount of lightning or thunder damage dealt, or temporary hit points granted by all three Arcane Duelist bonus action features increases by {@dice 1d6}.

subclassFeature.name: Master Wandslinger
entries: {@i 15th-level Wandslinger feature}
You have become a master of Wandslinger artifice. You gain the benefits listed below:

items: When you use your action to make an Arcane Sidearm attack, you can cast an artificer spell of 1st-level or higher as a bonus action on that turn.
When you cast an artificer spell and use your Arcane Sidearm as the spellcasting focus, you can choose for that spell to deal force damage in place of its normal damage type.
As a reaction when you, or a creature within 10 feet is targeted by a spell, you can grant all creatures within 10 feet of you three-quarters cover against that spell.
You can choose for your Arcane Duelist bonus actions to deal force damage in place of their normal damage.

subclassFeature.name: Aeronaut
entries: The most dangerous Specialization an artificer can pursue is that of the Aeronaut. Constantly carrying out dangerous trials in their pursuit of mechanical flight, these pioneering minds will risk anything to complete the perfect flying machine. No setback or injury can dampen the spirits of a true Aeronaut.

subclassFeature.name: Tools of the Trade
entries: {@i 1st-level Aeronaut feature}

You gain proficiency with {@item woodcarver's tools|phb}. If you are already proficient with woodcarver's tools, you instead gain proficiency with another set of {@item artisan's tools|phb} of your choice.

subclassFeature.name: Aeronaut's Harness
entries: {@i 1st-level Aeronaut feature}

When you adopt this Specialization, you craft for yourself the signature safety harness of an Aeronaut. You learn the {@optfeature skyfall harness|LLAART:E} Infusion, it doesn't count against your total number of Infusions Known, and you can ignore its level prerequisite.
However, until you reach 5th level in this class, only you can don the skyfall harness you create with this Infusion. For all other creatures, this Infusion fails to function.

subclassFeature.name: Aeronaut Spells
entries: {@i 2nd-level Aeronaut feature}
You learn certain spells at the artificer levels noted in the table below. These don't count against your total number of Spells Known and can't be switched upon gaining a level.

subclassFeature.name: Flying Machine
entries: {@i 3rd-level Aeronaut feature}

You have constructed the signature invention of an Aeronaut, the Flying Machine. Over the course of 1 hour, which can be during a short or long rest, you can use woodcarver's tools to craft a Flying Machine. Some Flying Machines include wings made of canvas, rotating blades, or even elemental engines.

Your Flying Machine can only be used by you and can be attached to your skyfall harness. While you wear your Flying Machine, you can use it as a spellcasting focus for spells. It also grants you a flying speed of 20 feet, and you can hover.
At certain artificer levels, this flying speed increases: at 5th level (30 feet), at 9th level (40 feet), and at 15th level (60 feet).
You can only maintain one Flying Machine, and creating a second one causes the magic of any others to dispel.

subclassFeature.name: Airborne Assault
entries: {@i 5th-level Aeronaut feature}

Your Flying Machine allows you to attack foes from unorthodox positions and catch enemies unaware. When you are flying at least 5 feet off the ground, your weapon attacks and artificer spell attacks deal an additional {@damage 1d8} bonus damage on hit.
At 15th level, this bonus damage becomes {@damage 2d8}.

subclassFeature.name: Aerial Maneuvers
entries: {@i 9th-level Aeronaut feature}
You have greatly improved the maneuverability of your Flying Machine. While you are flying at least 5 feet off the ground with your Flying Machine, you gain the following benefits:

items: You can use your bonus action to {@action Dash}.
You gain a bonus to your Dexterity ability checks and saving throws equal to your Intelligence modifier (minimum of +1).

subclassFeature.name: Master Aeronaut
entries: {@i 15th-level Aeronaut feature}

You have become a master Aeronaut. While you are flying at least 5 feet off the ground in your Flying Machine, and are subjected to an effect that allows you to make a Dexterity saving throw to take only half damage, you instead take no damage if you succeed, and only half damage if you fail.

subclassFeature.name: Archivist
entries: For centuries chroniclers have sought the best way to store vast amounts of information. While most were satisfied with scrolls, the Archivists looked for something greater. In their research, they learned to store libraries worth of information in objects, awakening the first Artificial Minds. Working with these wondrous Minds, Archivists wield the limitless power of these arcane intelligences to drive their research forward.

subclassFeature.name: Tools of the Trade
entries: {@i 1st-level Archivist feature}

You gain proficiency with {@item calligrapher's supplies|phb} and learn to speak, read, and write two languages of your choice. If you are already proficient with calligrapher's supplies, you instead gain proficiency with another set of {@item artisan's tools|phb} of your choice.

subclassFeature.name: Artificial Mind
entries: {@i 1st-level Archivist feature}

You learn to awaken mundane objects. Over the course of 1 hour, which can be during a short or long rest, you can use calligrapher's supplies to awaken an Artificial Mind in a Tiny nonmagical object you touch. While the object is awakened, it is a magical item that requires your attunement and can be used as a spellcasting focus for any artificer spells you learn.
Should you awaken a second Artificial Mind, any previous Artificial Minds are instantly dispelled. While attuned to the awakened Artificial Mind, you gain the following benefits:

entries.name: Magical Telephony
entries: You can communicate telepathically with any creature carrying one of your infused items within a 1-mile radius. The creature can also respond telepathically.

entries.name: Skill Proficiencies
entries: Depending on the material of the object you awaken, you gain proficiency in two skills of your choice from the corresponding column on the table below.

subclassFeature.name: Archivist Spells
entries: {@i 2nd-level Archivist feature}
You learn certain spells at the artificer levels noted in the table below. These don't count against your total number of Spells Known and can't be switched upon gaining a level.

subclassFeature.name: Information Overload
entries: {@i 3rd-level Archivist feature}

Your Artificial Mind can bombard other minds with psychic information. As an action, you can force a creature you can see within 30 feet to make an Intelligence saving throw. On a failure, it takes {@damage 1d8} psychic damage and has disadvantage on the first attack roll it makes before the start of your next turn.
